campaign.story:
Several groups of explorers have landed on a mysterious island.  Each group has encountered and aligned with a native tribe.  With the new explorers upsetting the delicate balance of the tribes, this once peaceful island has been set into chaos.  It will take one group of explorers to unite the tribes or kill off the opposing explorers to bring peace back to the island.
In Island Dice, players select strategic combinations from a variety of custom dice each turn.   You then execute your roll results in order to bring peace to the island.
This can be achieved in one of two ways:
You can unify all four of the native villages by protecting them simultaneously, bringing peace to the island.
OR
You can eliminate all of your opponents.  With no one left to fight, you have brought peace to the island, and you win.
Begin your turn by selecting three of the eleven Option dice.  You will then add the three Action dice and roll all six together.
Now choose which of the die rolls to resolve first and take its action.  Continue resolving your dice one at a time until they have all been used.
At any time during your turn, you may choose to spend some of your gems to help enhance your strategies.
 (above picture includes stretch goals #1 and #2)

This mysterious hole in the ground is surrounded by hundreds of years of bones and destruction. Mist, strange and continuous, flows up and out. A thin winding stone stairway travels either down into the unknown depths below or provides an escape for what lies, or lied within. This is a territory for no living person. The natives fear this place and will not enter its realm.
This hex is a promotional land tile. Natives will not and can not move onto this location. This provides a native free hideaway, but it is nowhere near safe. Both the Massive Roaming Karma, and the Big Nasty Guy can opt to spawn from this location when they are first summoned instead of their normal tiles. The cave and the ancient ruins are no longer the only dangerous spots. With this third spawning point, the danger and strategy only become greater.
 "It's a game I really enjoy" - Undead Viking
 "If you like chucking dice, but you want a little more strategy, definitely be sure to check out Island Dice." - Bower's Game Corner
 "The best part of the game is probably the chances that there's going to be at least one stand up dice roll moment." - Under 5 Minute Review
 "Island Dice is a fun game that is a little different, made by a company that's just starting out and actually needs your pledge.  I've played Island Dice, I like it, and unlike most games I play in the course of writing my blog I actually want to play it again.  So give it a shot, because when the Island Dice campaign is over there will still be plenty of Cthulhu games to pledge for on Kickstarter." - A Board Game A Day
 "it has a solid balance between skill and luck" - Cool Nerd Games

A light, trick-taking card game in which players take on the roles of thieves, mages, barbarians, and necromancers as they battle it out and attempt to be the first player to run out of cards.
An adaptation of the Russian card game Durak, Battle of Durak features new rules, complex strategies, and a role-playing fantasy twist.
Gameplay:
Players take turns attacking and defending with battle and skill cards in an attempt to add more cards to their opponent’s hands while depleting their own.
Strategic hand-building is key to winning the game. Hold on to the right cards, play your characters skillfully, and prepare for the final battle.
Mechanics:
•Trick-taking
•Hand-building
•Variable player powers
•Memory
•Player elimination
•Co-operative play
MSRP $18
Kickstarter price $14
*Combine Skill Cards from two decks and go head to head in battle using the same character classes! 
"Game cards look Amazing! All of them. Well designed." - Larry R. Cockrell Jr. - Kickstarter Game Projects - View Full Review
"It was an enjoyable play...Definitely an enjoyable filler." - Pat Johnston (Prototype Tester) - View Full Review
"It is my son's 2nd favorite game... and whenever we have a minute, he is begging me to pull it out and play him again." - Matthew Simpson (Prototype tester)
"...Brilliant game! Lots of back and forth at the end! Great Fun!" - George Stewart (Prototype tester) - Beards and Boardgames
Rated Top 5 Kickstarter Games - Jan. 18th 2015. Check out the review by MeepleMechanic HERE.
Designer Interview: Fedor Sosnin on designing Battle of Durak 
Become the almighty Mage and use magic and sorcery to manipulate the odds. 
Choose the powerful Barbarian and use brute force and strength to overpower opponents.
Be the sneaky Thief and use deception to trick your opponents.
Play as the deadly Necromancer and use the black arts to rule the graveyard.
Players will use Battle Cards to defend themselves and carry out attacks. 
There are 4 battle card suits: 
Battle of Durak will come in an extremely portable tuck box so you can bring the battle anywhere! 
Battle Events are cards that are shuffled into the deck before the initial battle begins. There are 4 events but only 3 get shuffled into the deck at random. Battle of Durak is all about efficiently playing cards that you are dealt and choosing the right skills to play at the right time. Battle Events are designed to throw players off their a-game, keeping all players on their toes. Just when you think you have the perfect cards in-hand, a dust storm may engulf the battlefield, you could get wounded, be pillaged, or even worse, taxed. 
The official game instructions can be found HERE.
Battle of Durak is played clockwise around the table through a series of attacks and defends. An attacking player can attack the opponent to their left with a battle card. The defending player then has a chance to defend that card with a card of higher numerical value or a trump suited card. Once defended, the attacker can continue their attack with cards that numerically match the cards in play. For example, if you attacked with a "6 of Stars" and it was defended with an "11 of Stars", you can continue your attack with any other 6 or 11 that's in your hand. If at any time a defending player can no longer defend against an attack, they have to take all the cards in the play area into their hand. So much for getting rid of all of your cards! If an attacker's cards where defended, the cards in the play area are moved to the graveyard and the defender gets a chance to attack the opponent to their left.
Don't forget about your powerful, game-changing skill cards! Each character has unique skills that will aid you in battle. Each player will hold 3 of 5 skill cards along with 6 battle cards in hand to unleash lethal combos.
Want to play the game before funding? All you need is your favorite deck of playing cards and the Print & Play edition of Battle of Durak. Download the skill cards HERE.

Orléans is for 2-4 Players aged 12+, taking 90 minutes. Now with all English language on the board.
For $57 you can get our special Kickstarter Deluxe edition, with metal coins and wooden tokens instead of cardboard. And for just $2 more, you not only get the deluxe edition of Orleans, but also a TMG original game by Andy Van Zandt, Bottlecap Vikings!
A Brief Description of Orléans
During the medieval goings-on around Orléans, you must assemble a following of farmers, merchants, knights, monks, etc. to gain supremacy through trade, construction and science in medieval France.
In the city of Orléans and the area of the Loire, you can take trade trips to other cities to acquire coveted goods and build trading posts. You need followers and their abilities to expand your dominance by putting them to work as traders, builders, and scientists. Knights expand your scope of action and secure your mercantile expeditions. Craftsmen build trading stations and tools to facilitate work. Scholars make progress in science, and last but not least it cannot hurt to get active in monasteries since with monks on your side you are much less likely to fall prey to fate.
Image Credit: Steph Hodge Photography
In Orléans, you will always want to take more actions than possible, and there are many paths to victory. The challenge is to combine all elements as best as possible with regard to your strategy.
Orléans English Rulebook (4MB PDF)
Image Credit: Steph Hodge Photography
The Deluxe Edition
For the Orléans deluxe edition, we have made the following upgrades to the base game:
Provide Metal Coins (we still include the cardboard tokens)
Wooden Discs + Stickers are available for the workers. (we still include the cardboard tokens)
In addition to these, we can unlock with Stretch Goals further improvements to the components as detailed further down below.
We will only be manufacturing the deluxe editions once. Other than some extras made to cover damage, loss, and a few convention sales, they will not be available again from TMG.
The cost to upgrade to Deluxe Edition matches our cost to produce the upgrades.
Tom Vasel Reviews Orléans
 Rahdo's Final Thoughts On Orléans
 If you would like to see Rahdo's run-through of the gameplay, click here.
And if you want the extended gameplay, well... Then, click here.
Use this area to get rid of undesired workers and gain a one-time reward Image Credit: Steph Hodge Photography
Stretch Goals
FUNDED! @ $60,000 Funding - Add 16 wooden wheels to the deluxe edition for use in place of the technology tokens.
FUNDED! @ $80,000 Funding - Add 14 meeples to the deluxe edition for use in place of the various citizen tokens
FUNDED! @ $100,000 Funding - Add 4 custom meeple shapes to the deluxe edition for each of the individual players.
FUNDED! @ $125,000 Funding - Tavern & Depot tiles will be included for the deluxe edition of Orléans
FUNDED! @ $185,000 Funding - Add 90 wooden goods tokens to the deluxe edition of Orléans. This does not replace the cardboard pieces.
@ $210,000 Funding - We will double the stickers for your worker wood.
What is Bottlecap Vikings?
Bottlecap Vikings is a small box game (like Harbour or Dungeon Roll) internally developed here at TMG and designed by one of our game developers Andy Van Zandt.
The not yet quite finished cover for Bottlecap Vikings.
If you are pledging for the Deluxe Edition of Orléans, it is only an additional $2 to get Bottlecap Vikings, and well worth it. This is not a game on the scale of Burgoo or Coin Age, but more like Harbour or Dungeon Roll.
It is a quick and variable rondel game which has your decisions heavily influenced by where other players are. The rondel setup is variable, and so are the player powers...
Update #5 was all about the game if you would like to read more about it.
What If I Want Multiple Copies?
If you would like to pledge for additional copies at your tier level, then please just add the base cost of the tier again.
So, for example, just add $59 to get an additional Deluxe Orléans and Bottlecap Vikings. Limit 4 total outside of the USA for shipping costs purposes.
Why USA / Canada / Australia Only?
The nature of our agreement with game publisher DLP and the designer Reiner Stockhausen is such that we are only able to sell in the USA, Canada, and Australia on Kickstarter.
Once this Kickstarter is over, then we will only be able to sell in the USA and Canada.
The tracks where you collected workers and rewards. Image Credit: Steph Hodge Photography
Why Kickstarter?
We LOVE Orléans here at the TMG headquarters. We personally believe that it was the best game released at Essen in 2014, which says a lot since we also like AquaSphere very much.
We love the game so much that we wanted personally to have premium versions of the game. Now, the cost to print and sell these through distribution is just too high!
So, we have added our cost of the deluxe upgrade to the game to the Kickstarter price without any profit added in. We want as many people to be able to have this as possible and we hope that you decide to order on this Kickstarter project.
Also, if you have Belfort, Village or Harbour, then you know that we like to have stickers on wood. Nothing says "TMG" quite like having to put stickers on wood.

campaign.story:
Ancient Balinese legend describes a host of powerful spirits who help poor rice farmers achieve success. These farmers have long used a sophisticated irrigation system to organize rice cultivation by integrating religious devotion and social responsibility with traditional farming methods. Even modern farmers seek to placate the spirit world in their quest to produce an abundant harvest.
In Spirits of the Rice Paddy players compete against fellow rice farmers to construct and tend rice paddies. Livestock can be used to build walls and remove large rocks. They can eat harmful pests and fertilize the fledgling crops. Weeds must be kept at bay. And, most importantly, water must be conserved and released with the greatest of care. With a little luck, all that back-breaking labor will pay off in the end. The good news is that the spirits are eager to assist, granting many special abilities, blessings and magic. The farmer who produces the most rice over seven rounds wins!
We thankfully had several requests from industry professionals interested in an early glimpse of Spirits. Here's what they had to say!
Richard Ham, the illustrative reviewer and creator of Rahdo Runs Through played Spirits and called it "a perfect, wonderful farming simulation with a brilliant, engaging puzzle to solve..." and "one thing we don't see enough of in games - a really great sense of escalation."
As usual, he does an extremely thorough run-through (and static-cam here).
You can also see his extended gameplay video (and static-cam here).
Ryan LaFlamme of Cardboard Republic sat in a game of Spirits at Gen Con, and he also graciously agreed take a copy home to play. Here's his preview.
He also says that Spirits creates "a farming atmosphere with a flavor all its own."
Heavy Cardboard included Spirits in its most-anticipated games of 2014 list. They opened episode 15 with this preview.
Jason at Indie Cardboard graciously looked at Spirits. It wasn't quite his cup of tea, but the preview is quite informative.
G*M*S Magazine interviewed Philip about Spirits. Listen to it here.
Meeple Mechanic does a Foxhole Fiver with Philip duBarry.
Spirits of the Rice Paddy is a big game, Here's a breakdown of the components:
 Additional components will be added to this list as stretch goals are met.
Spirits of the Rice Paddy is a medium to heavy Euro agriculture simulation. It is a worker placement game with several other interesting and complex elements. 
What makes Spirits interesting to me, and the reason I decided to pick the game for publication is the interaction between Spirit cards and player order, which creates a unique puzzle for how each game is played.
Spirit cards dictate the order that players get the most precious commodity - water. Spirit cards with high numeric value are extremely powerful. Playing high-numbered cards grant tremendous powers BUT you'll get water after other players with lower-numbered Spirit cards. 
Water is the most important commodity in the game - necessary to plant and grow rice. Players that don't get water risk wasting seasons without planting.
Each player has a market from which they can hire laborers and buy livestock. Laborers can build paddies and plant, weed and harvest them. Livestock (oxen) can build paddy walls and remove rocks from the field as well as remove pests and fertilize fields (ducks). Taxes apply when getting multiple items on a turn, so even though rice/money is tight it's important to get items early to avoid late-game taxes.
You can get more information about Spirits on the game's page at apegames.com.
You can download the rules from apegames.com. 
Philip duBarry is the designer of Revolution!, Courtier, and several other board games and expansions. Philip has been playing and creating games since childhood and has done so on a professional basis for about the last six years.
Spirits has been in the works since 2010 and is perhaps his most heavily playtested game to date. He lives in Cincinnati with his wife and five (soon to be six!) children.
Friend and really smart guy Brendon Hall has built an online boardgaming engine that has worked really well for testing and playing Spirits of the Rice Paddy. 
We'd like for you to play Spirits online with us so that you can learn about the game. To that end we're scheduling game nights with the designer, Philip duBarry. Watch the project post updates and this space for more information on the first game night! 
If this project exceeds its $16000 funding goal, we'll upgrade items, and add new items to your pledge levels as the total reaches the indicated amounts.
Philip designed solo rules for Spirits of the Rice Paddy from the start. This stretch goal includes a new solo player board, rain cards and rules for solo play at no extra charge. 
These components won't be available in the retail product - only as part of this Kickstarter and afterwards directly from APE Games at an additional cost.
This goal will be to upgrade the 80 wooden laborers in the game from standard meeples to more thematic rice farmer meeples, similar to this:
The game box, cards, die-cut tokens, player boards and main board are upgraded to have a linen-like finish.
We hate it on games when you jostle the board and pieces go everywhere. This stretch goal provides two-level player boards with 'grooves' for the paddy walls and market laborers and livestock. Table jostles will be no problem!
By popular request we're upgrading the green and black weed and pest cubes to actual meeple components!
Arcadia is APE's card game of building theme parks. Have you ever gone to an amusement park and thought that roller coaster would be so much better if they only added a couple corkscrews after that first drop? Well here's your chance to build a theme park for the ages! 
Arcadia is a card game of building amusement parks for 2-4 players, aged 8+. 
In Arcadia, players collect job and expert cards -
Then trade them in to build rides, midway games, food stands and shows of ever-increasing complexity.
There's more to it than that, so head to apegames.com to see more!
Arcadia will be published at the same time as Spirits. There are pledge levels here that let you add Arcadia at a discount.
We know there are a lot of tabletop game choices on Kickstarter, so why back Spirits? 
For starters, APE Games really does need your help to ensure Spirits gets printed. This will be the most expensive game to print since Rolling Freight, so we can't do this without you!
Second, depending on stretch goals achieved, Spirits will cost at least $50 in stores, so you'll get a substantial discount off the retail price.
Also, assuming we hit the solo game stretch goal, the solo board and cards won't be available in stores.
As always, shipping in the U.S. is free, and reduced in the rest of the world. We'll ship from within Europe, Canada and of course, the U.S.
There are some other projects that you should check out on Kickstarter. One such project is Swinging Jivecat Voodoo Lounge. The art is awesome and... monkeys hung on martini glasses for scoring!
Cards contain recipes for drinks, and they made up a new 'Spirit' for our game!
Go take a look at it!

Each copy of I Hate Zombies you pledge for currently comes with the following:
1) The IHZ Base Game, containing 12 character cards, a card for use with an odd number of players, and the rules.
2) Six bonus character cards which have been unlocked via this Kickstarter campaign!  These characters will NOT come in the base game for non-backers that buy the game later, but will be available for $5 from the Geek Store.  So, you get $5 worth of extra goodies for free!
Yes, Unique Zombie Art for Each Character!
With the final stretch goal reached, we've given Robb the green light to ink and color all of the zombie sketches!  Here's a preview of all of them!
Yet again, a ravening horde of horrible zombies has shambled forth to devour the living. It must be a day of the week that ends in ‘y’.
In I Hate Zombies., designed by acclaimed game designer, Kevin WIlson, 2-12 players face off in a climactic battle for the very fate of the world that will last about 10 minutes. Some of the players will be the noble last survivors of humanity, while others will be dirty, wretched brain-guzzling zombies. To see who survives, they will engage in that time-honored tradition, that Sport of Kings...
Yes, that's right. Rock-Paper-Scissors. To the Death!
Although the valiant humans each have a special ability to aid them in their struggle to survive, the zombies are tougher to kill, and humans they kill turn into more zombies, and certainly let us not forget the spleen-churning stench.
While the game could be succinctly described as Rock-Paper-Scissors with special abilities, the abilities add some interesting decision making for the zombie players as to which humans to focus their brain munching beam on, and when. So, while the game uses the RPS mechanism, there are real and interesting decisions to be made which will have the zombies debating their strategy (or at least as well as their limited mental capacity allows).
If you hate zombies (and you should!), you'll find altogether more zombies than you're comfortable with in I Hate Zombies.
We could blather on about how to play the game here, or we could just link you to the rules. The simple rules all fit on 4 small pages, so you can likely get the gist of it in a couple minutes!
Download the Rules Here!
Want to play the game now?  We've even put together a print and play set of the game for you to download!  The game is only 13 cards, with a front and back side for each, so just follow the short assembly instructions via the link below and you'll be playing in no time!
Download the PnP cards here!
Some of you might absolutely love playing RPS and you're already sold.  Awesome, you'll have a great time!  However, the rest of you are scratching your head and wondering how this is anything more than repeatedly playing RPS with a scoring system. We think you'll still have a great time, but let's show you a little more...
Granted, the game is a very light party-style game any way you slice it, but the fun of the game really arrives in the special abilities of the human characters, and how they can end up interacting in the game! They can really put the zombie scum in a bind, which is exactly where we like seeing them. So, let's check out the motley crew that will be fending off the horde:
Athlete: The athlete's competitive spirit means he's going to win, and he's going to win a lot!  Zombies aren't going to want to mess with him if they can help it.
Biker: The biker is fearless and will step in to sucker punch any zombie that comes near her!  The zombies are going to want to take here out before she punches out what little brains they do have.
Bulldog: The bulldog is one serious threat, and may kill a zombie in one chomp!  A weakened zombie may find him to be a less risky target, but if a zombie is still in good shape, he may want to avoid this fella.
Businesswoman: Her game function is essentially the same as the bulldog, but she'll beat you with her smarts instead!
Cheerleader: A fairly easy target for the zombies, but if she sticks around, she'll make everyone around her even meaner with her inspiring cheers!
Couple: Strength in numbers!  There's two of 'em, so they're twice as hard to kill!
Hunter: The zombies do not want to cross the hunter!  Not only will he set his sights on a zombie, but the bullet will fly into another zombie as well!
Nurse: While she may look harmless, her healing abilities are a serious pain in the neck to the zombie horde!
Policeman: The law is going to come down on the zombies HARD! When the policeman gets a shot off on a zombie, he's going to feel it.
Scientist: The pesky scientist has come up with an antidote!  Instead of dying, any zombies next to her will regenerate into a full healed human again.
Sniper: The sniper is always looking for a zombie to finish off.  He can set his sites on any zombie of his choosing when he wins a fight!
Soldier: The last of the insta-kill trifecta of cards (along with Bulldog and Businesswoman).  These abilities are a big risk for zombies, and can also really mess with their heads!
Whichever human (or zombie, should you be so unfortunate) you control, you'll find yourself yelling and cheering for you and your fellow teammates, as the fate of the world hinges on each and every battle!  You'll also find many interesting scenarios emerge, as we'll now see...
We totally understand! So far, it's just us project creators telling you how cool the game is, and of course we love it or we wouldn't be making it.
UndeadViking is the first reviewer to review IHZ!  If you've never watched his videos, you really should!  He is one of the most thorough, thoughtful reviewers out there, besides just being an all around good guy.  Furthermore, he doesn't accept payment for his reviews, so you know his opinion isn't based on us throwing a bunch of dollars at him. He just has a real passion for games and reviewing them, and it shows!
If you enjoy Lance's review, make sure to subscribe to him on YouTube, where he does very excellent, in depth reviews of all kinds of games.
Here's an example of a scenario you might come across in IHZ. Let's pretend you've been duking it out for bit, and it's now zombie A's turn.
Zombie A has previously sustained a wound, meaning attacking the Policeman is a risky move (remember, zombies thankfully die when they take 3 wounds, and the Policeman does two damage if he wins). Attacking the Policeman could spell his doom!
However, attacking the Sniper comes with a big risk as well.  Zombie A's incompetent friend, Zombie B, has already taken two wounds.  If the Sniper wins, he could choose to finish Zombie B off instead.  Worse yet, this means there'd be no one left to finish off that pesky Cheerleader, leaving her uncontested to cheer on the Policeman, a combination deadly enough to make any zombie shudder.
It's almost enough to make you feel sorry for the zombies!  Wait, no, never mind. We really hate zombies.
Most importantly, IHZ is fun, and we want it to exist! Have you not been paying attention to anything we've been saying!?!  If you like having fun with your friends, pledging for a copy (or two, or three, or five) would be a fun time for you when the game delivers. If the project doesn't fund, there will be one less fun thing in the world!
A generous royalty per copy goes to Kevin Wilson! If you play many games, you've heard of this guy.  He has some awesome game design credits to his name, such as A Game of Thrones, Descent, Arkham Horror, and Sid Meier's Civilization: The Board Game. At BGG, we want to support the awesome designers that bring these games to life. The % royalty we give on our micro games is very generous; we want to make sure Kevin can afford a good chainsaw should zombies arrive at his doorstep.
The profits go to supporting BGG! Whatever profit is made from the project goes toward supporting the BGG community. We're continually at work making improvements, and are working toward continually doing so. If you enjoy the new marketplace system that was recently completed, that's the sort of work that will continue to be underway!
Robb Mommaerts is awesome! If you've been looking at this project, and thinking, "Gee, these graphics and illustrations are really nice!", you can thank Robb.  He's an amazing illustrator, and his contributions have really made IHZ into not just a fun game, but an outstanding overall product that we're really proud to present.  We would love to pay him for even more eye-popping illustrations, which brings us to...
We want to make IHZ even better!  We have some more cool ideas for the game, but bringing them to life isn't without cost.  We'd like bigger cards, more cards, and more of Robb's awesome illustrations, which all cost money that we can only afford if they're diluted by economies of scale.  So, more copies sold equal more cool things we can add!  More specifically, here's what we'd like to do...
Zombie Meeple Marker - $3
For $3, we'll add in a zombie meeple to your pledge rewards!  Just add $3 to your pledge for each meeple you would like shipped along with your games! The zombie meeple is great for marking the active zombie, which is especially useful in lower player count games to keep track of which zombie is currently attacking!
The meeple is Meeple Source's Mega Meeple size, which is about 19mm x 19mm.  A huge thank you to http://www.meeplesource.com/ for helping us make this item a reality.  If you haven't checked out their site, you really should, as they have all kids of awesome gaming accessories!
Brain Life Point Counters - $5
For just $5 for a set of 24 counters, you can add a set of brain life point counters to your game of IHZ.  Just add $5 to your pledge for each bag of brains you would like shipped along with your games!
The game is perfectly playable without these counters, but they definitely add some bling, and are a little neater to play with than the card rotating option.
Please note that the color may not match exactly what is shown in these images, as these are the prototype brains.  The shape and size is all set, however!
The Salesman promo card will be free to all backers, and later available in the BGG Store, so only backers will get the card for free!
The Miner promo card will be free to all backers, and later available in the BGG Store, so only backers will get the card for free.
The Priest promo card will be free to all backers, and later available in the BGG Store, so only backers will get the card for free.
 To better showcase Robb's awesome work, we'll be upgrading the card size to the size of the cards used in Dixit (which there are card sleeves available for!).  Bigger cards mean bigger illustrations! This is an upgrade to all copies of the game!
A trifecta of new characters!  These promo cards will be free to all backers, and later available in the BGG Store, so only backers will get the cards for free.
This will be an upgrade to all copies of the game!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
While this will be BGG's first published game, we don't anticipate any large risks or challenges in getting IHZ to you. The reasons being:

1) We've budgeted, budgeted, and budgeted again. The funding goal is enough to pay for the artwork, pay the designer, pay Kickstarter fees, get the games produced and shipped to our warehouse, buy envelopes for shipping, pay our warehouse staff, and pay the final shipping to you.

2) We're working with Ad Magic to produce the games. If you've never heard of them, they also handle the production of a little game called Cards Against Humanity (you may have heard of it, and if you haven't you must live in a cave). So, this isn't Ad Magic's first rodeo! Once I get them the files, they're responsible for the whole production process and getting the games to our warehouse in Texas, which they have done countless times with other games. So, we're letting a solidly proven professional handle all aspects of the process that we're unfamiliar with.

3) We're used to shipping large number of orders from the Geek Store. Our store staff should be able to ship out the orders rather efficiently once the games arrive from Ad Magic!

The main possible delays will be due to the stretch goals and needing Robb to do the extra illustrations for them, which will take some time. However, Robb has been an absolute joy to work with, and has already agreed to take on the extra work should you all make it possible!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
I just wanted to post an update regarding the rubber band issue since it is the most common message I've been receiving.
As gamers, we all know rubber bands and playing cards don't mix. As such, I didn't think to specify to the factory to not use rubber bands, as it never entered my mind that they would possibly use them in the game packaging. So, I was as surprised as anyone when reports started coming in of rubber bands on the cards.

As of today, all orders are in the mail, shipped USPS First Class Mail.
For US-based backers, this means you should have the game in hand within a week. For the rest of the world, it may take up to 4-5 weeks, depending on your location, so at the longest, everyone should have the game by the end of September.
If there are any problems with your order, use the messaging system on Kickstarter to contact us, as things posted to the comments section might easily get missed.

Packing of the orders has started today, with the first shipments scheduled to go out this week! Our store staff anticipates a timeline of two weeks for all packages to be sent.
Glad to be at this final step of getting the game into your hands, and thanks for your patience on us being two months behind the anticipated timeline!

The shipment arrived at our warehouse a few days ago while we were at Gen Con, so it's almost time for them to start shipping!
Our Geek Store staff is readying everything for shipping and should have everything packaged and ready to start fulfilling orders within the next two weeks. We'll get another update out once the first shipments start going out.
We apologize for not quite making the original June goal, but are happy to be getting these into your hands soon!

updates.update_userinfo: I Hate Zombies is on US soil! Make sure to complete your surveys!
updates.update_content:
I just got an email from Ad Magic that the shipment is in the railyard waiting for departure, with an estimated date of arrived of July 27th.  So, we should be on track to begin delivery in August!
There are still a decent number of folks that haven't filled out their surveys yet, so make sure to do it soon!
Also, if you need to update your address or anything, make sure to do it soon to ensure your shipment goes to the correct address.
Woo, got a fun package in the mail today!  My apologies for the poor color and glare on these photos; I didn't have good light to work with today...

Just wanted to shoot out a quick update that we're now just waiting on IHZ to make it through the queue at the factory to begin production.  So, nothing happening currently, but I just wanted to update everyone since it's been a few weeks.
Due to a few longer than expected delays at various points in the production (all the art for the final stretch goal, in particular, set things back a bit), it looks like we'll be a bet behind the expected ship date of June as well.  We're likely looking at August at this point since the game isn't quite being printed yet, and then the games have to take the boat across the ocean to the US.  However, there are no major setbacks yet, just minor things that all added up to a couple weeks at a time in delay.
Just a heads up that I received the proof sheets today!  These are just print outs of all the graphics to ensure the colors and everything look correct.

Just a heads up that the files for IHZ have just been submitted to our awesome friends at Ad Magic, who are doing all the coordinating on printing and shipping the games to us.  The next step will be the final proofs, and then on to printing once we're happy with the way the proofs look!
Ad Magic says we're still on pace to receive everything in June.  The plastic brains are already at the warehouse, and the zombie meeples are also due to arrive in June, so everything is on pace.
I'll just let Robb's excellent work speak for itself!

campaign.story:
Thanks to the incredible support of the backers, the game is over 450% funded and greenlit! Also I want to thank the games press for giving this little project some coverage- especially Rock Paper Shotgun and Kotaku.
A mock-up image of 'night mode', one of the stretch goals now reached!
Concrete Jungle is a new take on the city building game that swaps micro management for deck-building and extra servings of strategy.
The game combines the simple but satisfying mechanics of a tabletop deck-building game,
the intricacy and accessibility of an indie title,
and the variety and depth of a collectible card game.
Topped with the isometric stylings of classic 90s management sims!
You use cards in your deck to place buildings, clearing city blocks to give yourself more room to build. As your city grows you'll get opportunities to hone your deck, but the game also gets harder.
It started off years ago as a sequel to my indie game 'MegaCity' from 2011. Although still a successor to that game, it's come so far I thought it had earned a shiny new name.
The game is being developed for PC but I'll also be porting to Mac. Ports to Linux, Android and iOS may also be possible further down the road.
*sound of traffic*
You have a deck of selected cards which you can use to place buildings. Each building will affect it's surroundings in different ways. The aim of the game is to clear city blocks by gathering the required number of points from your residents, giving more room to build.
As the city grows, you choose bigger and better new buildings to add to your deck!
As you get opportunities to hone and refine your deck, residents will demand more from you, making the game harder. You'll find yourself inadvertently creating zoning puzzles- playing against your own past planning decisions!
Also in the works is a competitive game mode where 2 rival city planners face off in a city planning dual. Incredibly tactical- your building placements and deck building skills matter more than ever here.
Is their new apartment building raking in tonnes of points? Place a landfill next to it to screw them over! It's like building a city through playing chess- if chess was much, much meaner. There will also be AI to play against in this mode.
The game does not feature free-to-play mechanics or micro-transactions. There will be plenty of unlocks, but you'll have to earn them!
Planned features:
Over 150+ buildings! 50 more in a free update after release.
Single player story mode with 6 unlockable characters! 2 more in a free update after release.
Voice acting for the characters!
Online High Scores system!
Competitive mode with challenging AI!
Local competitive/co-op multiplayer for up to 4 players (1 vs 1, 2 vs 2)
Soundtrack featuring DP Kaufman, Mokhov & Xerxes and original music.
A night time mode- see your city lights at night! (Will also be in the free update).

Combo buildings together for maximum points.
Build your deck as you build the city!
Although I have a functioning build I'm really happy with, it only represents the beginning of what I want this project to be.
As the sole developer and artist, I can operate for next-to-nothing (but not quite nothing). The kickstarter funding will secure me enough time to implement the features listed above, as well as provide enough money to license the ideal soundtrack for the project.
I've organized the project for minimal risk- all the game mechanics are in place- what's left to do is add content and balance. Both of which are time consuming, but also in the grand scheme of things, relatively straightforward. That's not to under-estimate the challenges up ahead, but I'm fully confident I can deliver on this!
Early access funding is/was another potential route. However, as a gamer myself, I'm a little wary of this model. I feel it diminishes the release of the actual finished game- it's hard to keep track of a game when there's more than 1 release date!
Offering a preview build in a kickstarter campaign is a great comprise as it's limited enough to not deaden the final product, while giving you guys something cool to play in return for supporting the project.
The preview version of the game is already completely playable on PC and features 44 buildings. It's what I'm using to demo the game. You can get it right away after the kickstarter ends, along with a copy of the full game on release if you pledge just £5 or more!
The other backer rewards are filled with ways you can actually be in the game! There will be a large pool of random building names which will be assigned to every building each game. To add your name to the building databases, choose one of the pledges detailed on the right.
There are different databases. One is the citizen database, this will just use your or a name and apply it to a residence. Eg. 'Frank Callahan's House'
An example of your building names in the game!
The next is the city building database, which is unique for every other building. I'll sort out your submitted name into the correct category. For example, you could submit 'Frank's Firework Factory' and I'll make sure it only applies to factories. Or have a hospital named after you, eg 'Franklin's Hospital for Severe Burns'.
There is also a neighborhood database. In the game this applies to a group of buildings- real life examples would be the neighborhoods of SoHo or Tribeca in New York. This could be pretty much anything. 'The Firework District'.
Lastly, there's also a database for landmarks, which are top-end buildings. Think of them as statues or monuments. Eg 'The Frank Callahan Memorial'.
For the top tier rewards, I will get in touch with you to create your buildings/character!
I reserve the final say over what makes it in, but if I have a problem with your submission I'll get in contact to request a new one from you or suggest alternatives. I'm going to ask we avoid blatant advertising, submissions of bad taste etc. Names are fine. Puns are encouraged!
The campaign has had an incredible response! So much so that we're already funded & greenlit! So what now?
I asked the backers to vote on how the extra funds should be used (if you're a backer, check update #4), and the favorites were expansion of the game (more buildings and characters) and more visual effects (night mode, weather etc).
So I'm going to be putting the extra funding towards those- details further below.
I've also had a lot of advice relating to stretch goals- adding more content inevitably takes more time. I want to do what I can to meet my original planned release date and get a finished project out there for you. 
So my plan is to complete the game to the standard above, release it, then use the extra funds to expand it for free. I'm also going to be using some of the money to hire people to help with the workload in the meantime.
This is the best of both worlds as you guys will get the game on time, and you'll get the extra content later on for no cost!
So this is the content I'm looking at adding after release, for free:
+50 more buildings! Every time we break a new £500 barrier from 8k onwards, I'll add another 5! (I'm going to have to cap it at 50 though folks, I'm running out of building ideas!) GOAL REACHED!
+2 new characters!
+Night mode! It's a nice visual change, and it just looks cool! It's something I've wanted to include since the start but involves a lot of work as each building will have to have a 'night time look' created for it. I've done a quick mock-up of how I want it to look above. GOAL REACHED!
 +Other VFX: I'm going to look into doing some rain effects, and I'd like to get some people on the streets. The only thing stopping me from promising this right now is I'm not sure how it will impact performance on the engine I'm using. Will do this if possible!
+Language support: I'm already going to put some of the extra money to making sure the game supports some other languages. Details will be confirmed towards release. French, Spanish & German at the minimum.
+Expanded soundtrack: As well as the aforementioned licensed tracks, I'll also be adding some original music to the game in the form of a 'main theme'. Guaranteed @ 11k!
+Voice acting: I think this could be really cool (especially for a tutorial and the story mode). Consider it guaranteed if we pass 12k!
   Here are the best ways to follow the project (aside from through kickstarter of course):
colepowered.com or concrejunglegame.com
Developer's Twitter
Concrete Jungle Twitter
Facebook
IndieDB
Greenlight Page
If you are a member of the press, you can find a presskit here.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
I want you to be able to back my project with confidence. That's why I've minimized potential risk by holding off on launching this campaign until I had a preview version playable and ready.

I want to give you something to play now that's worth your money in its current state and will only get better towards release. It's not just a promise of a project- there's a lot here to play already.

I've also tried to make the funding goal as reasonable as possible. I'm able do this because I'm the sole developer, and there are very few additional costs- the main one being music licensing.

I've currently got a release penciled in for May 2015. It's possible that the project will be completed before then if everything goes smoothly, but I'm trying to plan for everything. As a backer, you will be notified of any delays or hiccups.

Along the way I'll be sharing with you as much of the development process as possible. I'll be writing dev blogs and improving the game with your feedback throughout the rest of the project. There are forums set up at colepowered.com for your input.

Thanks for reading! I hope I've shown you enough to earn your support. I can't wait to get started on the rest of this project!

updates.update_content:
Like clockwork- here's this week's update!

campaign.story:
In this small card game, players spread rumours (using the confused memories of the Prince to their advantage) to make him come to believe that your servant, friend or relative is in actuality Cinderella. Can you persuade the Prince to marry who you desire? Of course, other informants are spreading rumours and gossip about their own candidates, so you must be prepared to assertively dismiss some of what others will tell him, without giving away your true intentions.
Many possible Cinderellas will be offered to the Prince. Who will he believe and which "Cinderella" will he decide to marry?
Please note that the game shown in these videos is the original, Japanese version.
>> Board Game Brawl previews Too Many Cinderellas:
"There’s a surprising amount of depth here...It’s a unique theme that you don’t see much of and it’s going to appeal to a lot of people...A surprising amount of game in that very small box." - Nick
>> Bower's Game Corner previews Too Many Cinderellas:
"Overall - highly recommended, really enjoyed it, good humour, good gameplay, great little micro-game, check it out!" - Forrest
>> The Push Your Luck Podcast reviews Too Many Cinderellas:
Listen to the 44th episode of the Push Your Luck Podcast by clicking the following button (the review of Too Many Cinderellas begins at 46:07):
"It was a pretty awesome surprise... It is hilarious... last night I almost got him married to the cat... Everyone always plays it again." - Jonathan
>> The Inquisitive Meeple interviews Grail Games' David Harding:
Click the icon below to read Ryan's interview with David, discussing Too Many Cinderellas and all things Grail!
Too Many Cinderellas is a small game that packs a punch. Included in every copy will be:
- 18 Cinderella cards (63x88mm)
- 9 Yes/No cardboard voting tokens
- 1 Rules Booklet
(And, upon reaching stretch goals - see below)
- 9 plastic diamonds- 1 drawstring bag
All in a two-piece cardboard box (11cm X 11cm X 5cm)
The rules of Too Many Cinderellas are few and straightforward. Players begin the game with four cards, one of which they hope will be married to the Prince! On their turn, players will play one card to the table, using it as a rumour to support their candidates or remove others' from the running. All players then have a chance to permit or veto this rumour. At the end of the round, players reveal any remaining candidates to the Prince for his offer of engagement.

Watch a game being played! Please note that this is a 2-player game. Paying with 3-4 players works a little differently - please read the rules above for more details.

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Too Many Cinderellas has been available to purchase in Japan since earlier this year. It has already been enjoyed by many gamers and is finished - ready to go into production! This, plus the fact that the majority of games will be shipping to backers directly from the same neighbourhood as our manufacturer, means that shipping times should be comparatively quick.

One Zero One (Grail Games' first Kickstarter success) is due to be received EARLY by backers in January 2015. Grail is beginning to forge a track record of delivering fun games on time!

However, unforseen circumstances can hold up a project. This can happen at the point of manufacture or shipment. Grail Games has given a six-month time-frame for delivery of Too Many Cinderellas which we feel is substantial for a finished game of this size. If anything does affect the project, backers will be kept in the loop via regular backer updates at every step of the production and shipment process.

Please note: By pledging money towards this campaign, you are not pre-ordering the game, but helping us to make it a reality. Thank you for your support! Pledge levels do include all shipping costs, and backers will receive their games before retail stores, but Grail Games cannot guarantee that retailers will not sell Too Many Cinderellas at a cheaper price than Kickstarter supporters will “pay.”

Also, Grail Games will happily send replacement copies of any game damaged in shipment to backers, etc., but if backers fail to inform Grail Games of a change in shipping address or similar, backers may be asked to pay extra costs for a replacement copy of the game.

The terraform era has finally dawned on mankind.
In Outer Earth, each player controls a development company trying to establish themselves as leaders of the terraform industry by buying, building on, and selling planets for human habitation.
To turn opportunities into profitable victory points, players must practise lean resource management, shrewd strategic planning and gutsy foresight. The game ends when either the planets or bonus opportunities run out. 
The player with the most victory points wins.
Variable Game Length: At the beginning of the game, players can set up the game to be either a short (10min per player) or normal (20min per player) length game. The short game is great for new players to get familiar with the game.

Simultaneous Bidding: Players bid against each other in the galactic market to obtain the rights to build on planets. Planets have different attributes that affect company abilities and development capacities.

Dual Purpose Cards: Development cards are used for both buying and building on planets.

Pipeline System: All developments played on planets must connect to each other by following the cascading pipeline system.

Company Boost: Some planets provide additional benefits to company stats after they are sold. These benefits include either 1. an increase in the draw, build and/or launch attribute, or 2. a temporary worker.
"It's good to see Outer Earth's game designer intent on providing an excellent rulebook by getting a professional editor to take a look at their rules. I can guarantee you will be receiving a game with a quality rulebook that you can use to learn and start playing right away!"

Orbital ($200) and Universal ($500) components:Limited-edition plywood Company Boards (engraved with your logo/name!) and Bidding Paddles.
 3D-Printed space cow that is hand painted and finished.
$70 - Grid Poster
We ship a poster with all 30 of the illustrations in Outer Earth laid out in a matrix grid. It will have the designer and illustrator's name + the Outer Earth logo.
 $65 Level - Single Poster
You will get to pick ONE of the 30 images and receive a 16x16 poster with the selected image. There will be no branding of the Outer Earth logo or creators on this poster.
Can I add a poster to any pledge level?
YES! To add a poster to your existing pledge, increase your pledge level according to the type of poster (single or grid) and the number of posters you want. At the end of the Kickstarter, I will send out a survey verifying your order.
Example: If you have an Art Direct pledge ($150) and want 2 single posters (2 x $30) and 1 Grid poster ($35), your pledge would be 150 + 30 + 30 + 35 = $245
What is the poster quality?
The posters will be printed on an archival, acid free heavyweight matte paper stock.
Are there any additional shipping costs?
Since I will be using a Print on Demand service, you might have to pay customs fees on orders outside of the United States. However when pledging for a poster, everyone (US, INT', EU) pledges the same amounts ($30 and $35).
How are they shipped?
They will be rolled up and shipped in super-durable tubes!
The Kickstarter goal will fund an initial print run of 1000 units for Outer Earth. It includes shipping, basic distribution (in Canada + US), artwork and mandatory fees.
To ship Outer Earth, we will use a service called ShipNaked (a service used by Game Salute) and distribute the game through two different warehouse locations.
The first location will be in the US (that will ship worldwide excluding the US).
The second location makes the game EU friendly by shipping within the UK.

When the Kickstarter ends in November, we will have the resources to begin the completion of the digital files of Outer Earth. We will send and approve final proofs from prospective manufacturers by the beginning of 2015, allowing us to initiate production in March 2015. For optimal distribution to backers, the game will ship to two different warehouse locations. We expect the game to be in your hands by Early Fall 2015.
I started developing Outer Earth when I first heard about Cards Against Humanity's 2013 Tabletop Deathmatch. After being selected as one of the 16 finalists, I went to GenCon in the hopes of getting Outer Earth published.
While I did not get selected to win, the whole experience of meeting people in the board game industry was powerful and inspiring. It gave me incredible motivation to continue developing the game. Since GenCon 2013, every game element has been scrutinized, playtested and redrawn multiple times. Though the game has truly evolved from its humble beginnings, the essence of the game has not changed. The result? Outer Earth finally plays like the game I envisioned it to be a year ago, and it's much simpler and better than before.
My intentions are to keep improving Outer Earth up until the files are sent to the manufacturer. Although things might shift around ever-so-slightly until the very end, I am fully committed to delivering the best version of my game, Outer Earth, to you.
To provide the illustrations for the game, I have collaborated with Daniel Orellana; a friend, illustrator and a budding game developer (like myself!). He has been a part of the Toronto indie videogame development scene for a while, and Outer Earth will be his first illustration job for a boardgame. Working side-by-side with Daniel, we have created a utopian futuristic setting to bring to life the realities of terraforming to the game.

Whenever I need help in video, copywriting or general game design, I know that my sister (Fei-Ling Tseng) is there to bounce ideas off.
My girlfriend (Justine Wong) has endured my year long endeavour, supported me at GenCon and motivated me to make the best game possible.

This is the first time I'm publishing a game…

Thanks to all our Kickstarter backers for helping us make this game a reality!
Dragon Racer is a tabletop game that is easy to learn, but wickedly hard to master. It features a unique combination of card drafting and set collection that makes every game a new and exciting challenge. The base game comes with cards for 2-4 players, but if you add two sets together you can play with up to 8 friends. 
Time: 60 minutes (roughly 15 minutes per player)
Ages: 13+
Two years ago we set out to make a game that would be fun for both casual and experienced board game players. The sort of game you could play with your non-gamer friends and family that you would enjoy as much as they did. Countless iterations and hundreds of internal and external playtesting sessions later and we finally have a game we are incredibly proud of. Now we want to share the finished game with you! We hope you love Dragon Racer as much as we do and we hope you join us on our quest to make this game a reality.
Download our FREE Print & Play Prototype at our website!
Download the Prototype Game Rules!
Hate reading game rules? We do too! Check out our preview videos below to see some awesome rundowns of how to play!
In the game you play as a Dragon Racer, one of the few individuals talented enough to train and ride dragons through some of the most dangerous racecourses the world has ever seen. Your goal is simple; race faster and go further than any of your competitors.
The rules of dragon racing are easy; each racer has a team of three dragons to race with. The only problem is that it is very hard to encourage dragons to go the way you want them to. To get them moving you are going to need to enlist the help of other dragons from the surrounding area to cheer your dragons on. The faster the dragon, the more cheering dragons you are going to need to encourage it!
As the game goes on you will be able to switch faster dragons onto your team and use other dragons you collect to sabotage your rivals. In the end the winner will be the player who is able to make the best use of the dragons they collect.
Dragon Racer was designed with compactness in mind. We found we could fit all of the cards needed for 2-4 players inside one small box. But one of the great things about the game is its ability to play just as well with 3 players as it does with 8. With this in mind we designed the game in such a way that combining two sets gives you all the cards you need to play with up to 8 players.
Prototype Components Pictured
One Box of Dragon Racer Contains:
64 Dragon Cards
8 Trophy Cards
4 Double Sided Large Character Cards [+2 Bonus Cards!]
12 Large Race Track Tiles
8 Player Tokens [Dragon Meeples!]
1 Rulebook
The components shown above are prototype quality and the final version will include updated artwork.
Dragon Racer features the beautiful artwork of Rose "Rocky" Hammer (Drawings of Pokemon, try-hard Comics). Rose is a local Canberra designer who has been involved with the game and art design from start to finish. 
Our current prototype of the game uses Rose's art and the final version of the game will feature even more. The game's final artwork will include:
12 Different Dragon Card Illustrations
8 Different Character Illustrations
12 Visually Enhanced Track Cards
And More!
Each game of Dragon Racer lasts seven turns. Each turn players will simultaneously draft dragon cards from a collective pool. The goal is to collect the dragon cards you need to support your specific team of dragons. Unlike other drafting games, in Dragon Racer each round you have goals that you will either succeed or fail at - this creates an exciting and tactical drafting experience. Dragon Racer is built with a number of modern game design principles that make it an engaging game for players of all skill levels. To learn more about how to play download the rules, or check out preview gameplay videos below!
Why Casual Gamers Love Dragon Racer
Easy to Learn: Nothing turns off a new player quicker than needing to spend half an hour learning how to play a game. Dragon Racer has simple rules and was designed to introduce new aspects of the game in a logical order, making it very easy to learn as you play through your first couple of turns.
Simultaneous Turns: Since most of the gameplay in Dragon Racer happens whilst drafting, there is very little downtime in the game, keeping everyone active and involved at all times.
Perfect Length: Most games targeted at casual players are very short filler games. We wanted a game with a little more meat than that. We found that 60 minutes was "just right" for most players and with a set number of turns you know the game won't last longer than expected.
Great for any group size: Since you can play with as low as 2 and as many as 8 players, no one will need to sit out when you play.
Never Out of the Race: There is nothing worse than knowing you are going to lose a game and having to keep playing. Dragon Racer solves this problem by escalating the stakes each turn and giving small advantages to the players who are falling behind. So even if you fall way behind, it's always possible to win an 'Australian Skating Gold'.
 Why Experienced Gamers Love Dragon Racer
No Dice, Low Luck: Many games targeted at casual players are filled with lots of luck, randomness is the great equalizer. However we believe that too many random elements in a game lead to an unsatisfactory experience. While Dragon Racer does have some random elements, we keep skill and strategy at the forefront at all times.
Very Replayable: Every game of Dragon Racer is different. The character card you choose, the way the players around you are playing, and the track cards that flip all combine to make the game incredibly replayable. There are many different strategies and approaches to try out and the value of each is entirely dependent on the strategies your opponents take.
Rewards Advanced Skills: Card counting, statistical estimation, player psychology - all of these difficult skills can give you a great edge in Dragon Racer. Your ability to predict the outcomes of drafting decisions of other players will give you a distinct advantage.
Learn Fundamental Drafting Skills: From "Magic the Gathering" to "7 Wonders", drafting is an increasingly popular game mechanic. Dragon Racer is a "pure" drafting game and is perfect for honing your skills and learning how to excel at all types of drafting. Learning signaling and establishing what types are 'open' are just some of the basics this game will help you master.

Father Geek Game Review
Dragon Racer received the Father Geek seal of approval, being fully endorsed by separate gaming groups of children, parents, casual gamers, gaming elitists, and non-gamers!

We are offering you the exciting chance to permanently make your mark on Dragon Racer. Each copy of Dragon Racer comes with 64 dragon cards and each of those cards has a name. At this tier level you can work with us to name one of those dragons. This name will appear in every copy of the game ever made! Dragon Racer is a complete game, the challenges that lie before us are in the completion of our artistic goals and the process of manufacturing and shipping the final product.

We are confident in our ability to complete the remaining artwork in a timely manner at the same high level of quality you have seen in the artwork already revealed.

"Strife is one of the best games I have previewed in all my Critical Previews! Strife is one of the best games I have played in a long time, especially considering its size." - Tox, Crits Happen
If you like…
 - Intricate Ability Combinations
 - Strategic Deduction Challenges
 - Perfect Information Balance
 - Tarot-sized Cards
then Strife:LotE may be the perfect strategy game for you!
Strife, a two-player, tarot-sized, strategy card game that plays in around an hour, is a game of perfect information in which you always know your opponent's options. Aside from mastering the unique combo-creating gameplay of your champions, figuring out how to outmaneuver your opponent is where the true challenge lies.
Each player has the same hand of ten champions and will simultaneously play them as they fight over key locations throughout the world of Aerim, each worth varying victory points. Each champion has two abilities: a battle ability that's triggered during battles and a legacy ability that can be used only while on top of the legacy (discard) pile. This creates an intricate latticework of strategy for the players as each champion must be considered for not only what he can do in the current battle, but also for which ability he will add to the next.
Further impacting the critical decisions within the game is the Fatestone tie-breaking system. The Fatestone starts at a value of one, and whoever holds the Fatestone die loses all ties; that player may instead pass the stone to his opponent to claim a victory in that tie, but doing so raises the value of the Fatestone by one each time it is passed. At the end of the game, the player holding the Fatestone adds its final value to his victory point tally. Whichever player has the most victory points at the end of the game wins!
Want to try it out for yourself? Please check out our full Print-and-Play option below for everything you’d need (minus the die!) to delve into the world of Strife. This PNP is black & white and on poker-sized cards, but still contains the final rules, cards and artwork for the base game!

Inspired by Mexican Lucha Libre Wrestling, El Luchador Fantastico Grande challenges you to become either a hero in the ring, or a villain that teams up with other players and then chair shots them to the face!
El Luchador Fantastico Grande is a standalone card and dice tabletop game that challenges players to become Mexican wrestling super-stars. Players compete to see who can outlast and knock out all opponents, or team together in an exciting 2v2 tag-team mode. Are you ready to become the ultimate Luchador Wrestler?
The game contains 4x six sided dice, 4x twenty sided dice, 36 action cards, 6 wrestler cards (three male and three female) and one title belt card!
The artwork, by talented artist Frantz Kantor, is richly detailed and full of brightly colored Lucha Wrestlers. From the game's mechanics to its great characters, it combines the best of modern hobby gaming with the outlandish and colorful style of Mexican wrestling.
Why Your Support Matters
El Luchador Fantastico Grande was created by Al Caynes, who has founded Senyac Games to share his lifelong love of gaming. But to launch ELFG and fund his first tabletop game, Al needs your support!
El Luchador Fantastico Grande is a fully designed and play-tested, we just need that final push to finish the gorgeous art and get the game into production.
The basic $30 pledge level gets you the full game for $22 plus $8 postage anywhere in the world. Higher pledge levels also let you unlock awesome rewards like full uncut card sheets or the chance to put yourself in the game. As with any Kickstarter project, you're only charged if we hit our funding goal. And with your help, we can!
More About El Luchador Fantastico Grande
If you want to learn about the game, download the preview rulebook HERE.
This project is equality friendly, we have worked hard to ensure that both sexes are represented in equal light.
GAME PLAY VIDEO

All 12 stretch goals unlocked! Thank you!!! 
Vye has grown in quality and quantity since we first launched this kickstarter. The Kickstarter edition of Vye will now come with 110 linen finished cards, 125 wooden cubes, and a rule book, all in an upgraded awesome box. YOU made that happen.
If you missed out on the Kickstarter of Vye, but would still like to order it, you can do so at our company website: www.SandHatGames.com 
Thank you all again for the support and we’ll keep you updated on the development of the game as things progress. 
Joe, Doug and Vince of Sand Hat Games
“Vye is a kingdom building game at its most beautiful state.” Across the Board Games
“Would I recommend Vye? Without hesitation. It’s a fun and highly competitive card game of positioning and timing.” - Father Geek
Vye is an area control game that plays quickly across an ever increasing, and oftentimes contentious board, usually taking less than half an hour. The game is made up of 110 beautifully illustrated cards and 125 wooden tokens in 5 different colors. It has been favorably compared to Carcassonne, Fealty, Robber Knights and Go.
Vye is a game for 2-4 players, competing to build the largest kingdom... before the Inevitable Empress is drawn.  
Below is a quick "How to Play" video we put together for all of you. 
To play, you take five cards and lay them out as the unconquered lands of Vye. Players choose a color and put their matching house, and tokens in front of them. When played, each family member in a house claims neighboring cards with a unique trait. You’re dealt four cards and during your turn you can play from either your hand or from family. Playing your cards strategically enables you to capture your opponent’s lands and control the largest kingdom, thereby winning the game. Will you see your kingdom fractured or will you remain united and claim the kingdom of Vye before time runs out?
"Vye shines with its original artwork and design and is a terrific game to introduce to new gamers." Across the Board Games
 “Do play Vye the first chance you get and enjoy the challenge of capturing territory in an ever-shifting land dispute for power and control!” - Father Geek
We’ve had a lot of fun playing Vye and we’ve gotten a lot of great feedback and comments about the game. So much so that we wanted to give all of you the opportunity to try out our “pre-release edition” for free. Download the Print and Play of Vye below and if you like it please consider showing your support.
Download the Vye print and play kit here
Vye includes 60 Land cards, 20 Family cards, 24 special cards, 3 legendary cards, and an Inevitable Empress card. It also includes 5 different sets of colored wooden tokens (125 total) all in a beautifully designed box.
Update: Collector's Edition Box - $75 (Early Prototype)
Here's an early sample of the Collector's Edition box and tokens created by Lyris Laser Studio.
For more of an update on the Collector's Edition, check out Update #10.
Update: Release Party V.I.P. ($60) 
We have some more information regarding the "goodie bag" that comes at the V.I.P. pledge level.
 For more of an update on this pledge, check out Update #11.
All stretch goals are designed to add variety and mix up gameplay to keep you on your toes (as you Vye for control of the kingdom)! All stretch goals will be included in every copy of Vye.
Our first stretch goal is to upgrade our standard, and totally acceptable, card stock finish to the much more impressive linen finish. This gives the cards a thicker more durable feel.
Wild Lands: Vye is a magical place and sometimes lands don’t take form until the moment of choosing. The Wild Lands are 4 new bonus cards you can add into the deck. Wild Lands take on the aspect of a neighboring land when played.
Winter's Vale: High in the mountains of Vye, is a place where the snow never melts, called Winter's Vale. Winter's Vale is a new set of 4 land cards you can add to a game as a replacement for existing lands or to extend the length of a game.
Sinkhole: The world of Vye is falling into the earth. Giant, unexplainable sinkholes are swallowing up the lands of Vye making areas unpassable. Sinkholes are 4 new bonus cards you can add into the deck. They are placed on top of any existing land card. No kingdom can ever control that space again.  
Foxwood Marsh: Seeing the Foxwood Marsh, you might wonder why anyone would want to claim this foul smelling place for their kingdom. The creatures who live here are smarter, and more cunning than any animal should be. Some believe there is a Fox King at the heart of the bog ruling his minions with an ancient language only he remembers. The Foxwood Marsh is a new set of 4 land cards you can add to a game as a replacement for existing lands or to extend the length of the game.
Catapult: In the battle for the kingdom of Vye, sometimes it helps have reach. The families have brought their own weapons of war onto the battlefield. Catapult adds 4 new cards to the game. Each player adds a Catapult next to their house at the start of the game and plays it as they would a Family card. The Catapult allows you to claim a land previously out of your reach.  
Hungry Seas: The seas of Vye are ripe for conquering. It takes a boldness and bravery to sail these treacherous waters against the leviathans that call it home. The Hungry Seas is a new set of 4 land cards you can add to a game as a replacement for existing lands or to extend the length of the game.
Fortress: Command your ever-expanding kingdom with the indomitable Fortress. Providing you with a strong foothold in the contested lands of Vye, your Fortress can never be captured by your enemies and provides the lands surrounding it an imposing garrison. Fortress adds 4 new cards to the core set. Played from your sideboard along with your other Family cards, Fortress is sure to bring an exciting new dimension to your Vye games.
The Amber Jungle: What lurks in the remote depths of the Amber Jungle? Keep close watch as you explore the reaches of this newly discovered country, for predators known and unknown surely stalk this vibrant jungle land. The Amber Jungle is a new set of 4 land cards you can add to a game as a replacement for existing lands or to extend the length of the game.
 Undermine: Divided realms will be reunited with the powerful Undermine card. While you own Undermine, you may count the score from two of your kingdoms instead of one. Undermine adds 4 new cards to the core set and is sure to bring earth-shattering dynamism to your Vye games.
Drover Reach: The pastoral reaches of Vye are perfect additions to your burgeoning realm. Drover Reach is a new set of 4 land cards you can add to a game as a replacement for existing lands or to extend the length of the game.
The Lost City: The Lost Cities are thriving meccas of culture, influence and power. Long ago the inhabitants chose to remove themselves from society, learning to bend the minds of men to avoid their cities. However, you have found them and claimed their city as your own. The Lost City cards are 4 new bonus cards you can add into the deck. If they are in your largest kingdom at the end of the game, they increase your overall power.
Onyx Coast: Ancient castles stand vanguard over the realm known as the Onyx Coast. Their origins lost to time, these long-abandoned strongholds would be perfect conquests for your kingdom. Onyx Coast is a new set of 4 land cards you can add to a game as a replacement for existing lands or to extend the length of the game.
House of the Entangled Soul: Just who are these upstarts? Do they presume to divide your kingdom and take it for their own? Or will they be allies in your quest to rule Vye? The House of the Entangled Soul is a set of 4 new Family cards and 25 black tokens you can use in place of an existing family or to expand your Vye games to 5 player slug-fests! 
This stretch goal also unlocks an additional Catapult and Fortress card for the 5th family as well as 25 additional custom wooden tokens for the Collector's Edition version of the game.
Earthquake: The earth beneath your kingdom’s feet is not as stable as you might think. A sudden shift in the ground can cause lands you once controlled to slip away to a different part of the kingdom. In its place is a new land and potentially a new kingdom has appeared.
 Sanctuary: There’s a place in Vye, where even enemies coexist. This land is protected by the rulers of Vye and safe passage is always granted. The inhabitants are the castaway children of the houses - bastard sons and moon daughters. Though these children are not allowed in their own kingdoms, no house is willing to shed blood here, for fear that it would be their own.
 Necropolis: All things must die, but you can control who goes first. Watch how a kingdom’s forces, once powerful and mighty, turn to dust with the touch of the Necropolis.
Vye was created by three video game developers. We’ve spent our careers working on games such as inFAMOUS: Second Son, Diablo 3, Warhammer Online, City of Heroes, WildStar and more. Vye was developed in between two of those jobs. We wanted the perfect opener to getting hired: a game you could actually play in the interview, rather than just our resume of previous game experience. We knew the game would need to be quick to learn in order to immediately win over our audience of skeptical game developers. We never imagined that we’d create such a fun and beautiful game. Vye is that game and we can’t wait to share it with you.
Vye is in the final stages of development. The core game is solid and fun. We’re final testing some of the bonus cards to make sure everything flows smoothly. The art is being completed, with only a few cards remaining. We have our quote from our manufacturer and have determined how we’re going to fulfill orders when they come in.
All that remains is getting your support to make Vye a reality. If we hit our funding goal, we’ll be able to do a minimum print run of the game for you, the backers, and get Vye into game stores. We hope you’ll show us your support and back us.
  The three of us, Joe, Doug, and Vince, make up Sand Hat Games. We are a small company dedicated to making beautiful games for everyone to enjoy. Our professional background is in video game development, where we’ve spent years designing, writing and generally creating a lot of different games (Diablo 2, Diablo 3, City of Heroes, inFAMOUS, WildStar, and Warhammer Online). 
At home, we’ve worked on different projects from pen and paper RPGs to card and board games. Vye marks our first attempt to come together and produce something for everyone at Sand Hat Games, LLC. We hope to continue making gorgeous games that you love to play. Thank you for your support.
If you're interested in ordering multiple copies and are curious about what to add for shipping, please follow this handy chart below. If you are ordering multiple copies of the game please remember to add the proper shipping into the cost of the pledge. If you would like to add an additional copy or copies to an existing pledge, use this chart to determine how much extra to add to your pledge.
Sponsor Names
One of the amazing things about Kickstarter is that it allows the many to make the dreams of the few come to life. At the $100 and $125 pledge level we offer backers the chance to sponsor a card, much like a piece of art in a museum. The Kickstarter edition of Vye will display the sponsor names on the cards (See example below). The names are integrated well with the rest of the card making them both elegant and unobtrusive to players.
When you zoom in, the name looks like an etched glass plaque that’s been screwed into the card. It makes the card look like a museum piece.
We’re confident this will look elegant and we are testing it with actual cards to make sure the quality is up to our standards.
